report_title: Financial Planning and Advice Industry Report
executive_summary: The Financial Planning and Advice industry has experienced sustained growth over most of the five years to 2022. The industry comprises advisors and planners that provide financial advice in conjunction with other activities such as portfolio management, protection planning and brokerage services for households, businesses and governments. Advisors generate revenue through management fees taken as a percentage of assets under management (AUM) and a variety of other administrative fees. Affluent families tend to have a greater need for financial planning services, leading to increased demand for operators' services.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Industry growth over five years to 2022
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The Financial Planning and Advice industry has grown over the five years to 2022, propelled by burgeoning equity markets, healthy fixed income yields and growing assets under management (AUM) for a majority of the period. The rising importance of financial security, due to an aging population and financial market volatility, has resonated with many households and attracted more business to the industry.

Rising returns for client portfolios cause AUM to rise. A larger pool of assets results in higher management and other fees; consequently, industry revenue has increased at an annualized rate of 3.4% to $59.3 billion over the five years to 2022, including an estimated decrease of 7.5% in 2022 alone as a result of a sharp decline in S&P 500 and an increase in investor uncertainty.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The industry is expected to generate more revenue. However, economic uncertainty caused by the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic has led to substantial volatility in financial markets. This volatility is expected to affect total AUM and fees generated by industry operators in 2022.

Overall, these trends are expected to lead to industry revenue growth, which has risen an annualized 3.4% to $59.3 billion over the five years to 2022, including a decrease of 7.5% in 2022 due to a sharp decrease in the S&P 500 as interest rates climb to combat rampant inflation. Over the five years to 2027, revenue is expected to grow at an annualized rate of 0.5% to $60.9 billion. Similarly, steady AUM in the period is expected to lead to slightly improve industry profit.

industry_definition: This industry comprises companies that provide financial planning, financial advice and wealth management to individuals and business clients. Operators also offer advice in conjunction with other activities, such as portfolio management, protection planning and brokerage services. This industry does not include mutual fund companies, hedge funds, discount brokers, insurance brokers or other companies that deliver similar services outside the context of a written financial plan.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Higher employment, asset appreciation and disposable income
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Higher employment, asset appreciation and increases in disposable income result in individuals having funds to invest and seek professional advice.
The level of financial advice sought by corporations and institutions is tied to economic and financial market growth.
The aging US population is increasing demand for retirement and estate planning services.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Imports and exports do not apply to this industry. Most services are provided to US residents.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region has 22.3% of industry establishments, with Florida accounting for 8.3% due to its large retirement population.
The Mid-Atlantic has 16.1% of establishments, benefiting from proximity to New York's financial center. New York alone has 7.0% of establishments.
The West contains 18.8% of establishments, with California making up 14.1% due to its large population and wealth.
Other regions include the Great Lakes (13.3%), Southwest (11.3%), Plains (7.4%), New England (5.4%) and Rocky Mountains (5.4%).

regulations_points.regulation_description: The industry is regulated under the Investment Advisers Act of 1940, which defines investment advisors, requires registration, and details fiduciary responsibilities.
The Dodd-Frank Act and the SEC increased the asset threshold at which financial advisors must file for SEC registration.
The Department of Labor Fiduciary Rule expands the definition of 'investment fiduciary advice', requiring financial professionals working with retirement plans to be considered fiduciaries.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Before an individual can become a licensed financial advisor, they must pass exams like the Series 65, Series 7 and Series 66, which demand substantial costs and study time.
New financial advisors must spend time and money on lead generation, establishing referral networks, setting up presentations and purchasing prospect lists.
It is very difficult to start off in the industry with little experience, as prospective clients seek advisors with established track records and strong client bases.
The SEC's ongoing capital and regulation requirements, as well as industry best practices set by other organizations, provide additional barriers to entry.

basis_points.basis_description: Establishments compete for business based on brand recognition.

basis_points.basis_title: Number and range of product offerings
basis_points.basis_description: Establishments compete for business based on the number and range of product offerings.
Establishments compete for business based on the pricing of service-related fees.
Establishments compete for business based on the quality of research or advice.

concentration_points.concentration_description: One contributing factor to fragmentation is the high density of nonemployer operators (82.6% in 2022) who are sole proprietors providing services in their area.
The average employer establishment only has between four and five additional employees in 2022, limiting scalability.
Operators tend to build local clientele through face-to-face interaction, leading to geographic fragmentation.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The largest expense in the Financial Planning and Advice industry is wages. In 2022, wages are expected to account for 30.6% of industry revenue.
Expenses for purchases of data processing, communication and other services associated with office maintenance are expected to equal 2.2% of industry revenue in 2022.
Depreciation is expected to account for 0.8% of revenue in 2022, as operators do not rely on capital assets to conduct services.
Marketing expenses account for 1.2% as operators do not rely extensively on marketing services to attract new clients.
Rent expenses only account for 2.6% of industry revenue in 2022 since most operators are nonemployers or employ only a handful of employees.
Utility expenses account for 0.1% of industry revenue in 2022 since operators only rely on small office spaces.
Other costs include expenditure on information technology, data processing, computer equipment, legal expenses, and outsourced professional services. Other costs account for 46.0% of revenue in 2022.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The Financial Planning and Advice industry exhibits a low level of capital intensity. Wages are the most significant expense for industry establishments, consisting of 30.6% revenue.
Capital expenditures in the form of information technology (IT) spending are common in the industry, necessitating some level of capital intensity.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Low rate of new patent technologies
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The rate of new patent technologies entering the industry is low, which limits the potential for innovations.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Industry revenue closely follows the value and performance of the underlying assets under management (AUM), which are linked to changes in financial markets.
Industry profitability is tied closely to advisor productivity, which tends to be less volatile than revenue.
Economic uncertainty caused by COVID-19 threatened industry performance initially, but large market swings increased demand for services in 2020 and 2021.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Advancements in financial software have increased the productivity of investment advisors, streamlining operations.
The industry has started to experience technological disruption from robo-advisors like Betterment and Wealthfront that provide automated investment advice.

FAQs.question: How do you emphasize the value of your company's services?
FAQs.answer: As competition has intensified, financial advisers have had to become more versatile, offering various types of billing structures and a wider range of services.

FAQs.question: How has the shift toward conducting business online affected demand for your services?
FAQs.answer: The industry has experienced rising external competition from online discount brokers. The technology for do-it-yourself investing and financial information is widely accessible on the internet, enabling investors to conduct their own financial research.

FAQs.question: What is your company doing to reduce costs?
FAQs.answer: Operators have struggled to cut costs over the five years to 2021 due to rising competition in this industry.

FAQs.question: Are your operations spread across the country or are they more concentrated in a certain geographic location?
FAQs.answer: The largest companies in this industry usually have advisers spread across the United States, while smaller firms are localized in a certain area.

FAQs.question: How do you stay up to date with software and technology trends?
FAQs.answer: Staying up to date with the most recent technology and software trends is of paramount importance to industry operators.

FAQs.question: How have you taken advantage of rising online and mobile penetration into the financial services industry?
FAQs.answer: The largest operators have increasingly begun to offer online and mobile services in order to compete with discount brokerages.

FAQs.question: How do you expect the proposed changes to Dodd-Frank might affect your business?
FAQs.answer: Changes to Dodd-Frank could potentially lower costs and oversight on advisers in this industry.

FAQs.question: Have compliance costs been a hindrance to your company?
FAQs.answer: Compliance costs are significant in this industry and have increasingly slowed profit margin growth for industry operators.

FAQs.question: What methods have you adopted to improve cash flow in recent years?
FAQs.answer: Industry companies have increasingly shifted fee structures to reflect assets under management rather than investment performance to generate more steady cash flows during the period.

FAQs.question: How do your profit margins compare to those of your competitors?
FAQs.answer: The largest players in this industry are able to garner the highest profit, while the smaller players that struggled with significant competition over the past five years failed or performed poorly.

FAQs.question: Do you have a good reputation with your client base? How do you incentivize referrals?
FAQs.answer: A good reputation is extremely important for client acquisition and retention. A reputable track record attracts referrals, through which many investors often prefer to be introduced to a financial advisor.

FAQs.question: How do you maintain your client base? What promotions and marketing have you set in place to gain more clients?
FAQs.answer: Financial advisors generate the majority of their revenue through annual retainer fees and management fees based on a percent of assets under management. The ability to maintain clients is critical to growing the client book and generating revenue. Use of social media campaigns helps to reach out potential clients.

FAQs.question: How have you budgeted for research? What measures do you take to better understand the market?
FAQs.answer: Excellent research and understanding of financial markets will improve investment performance and increase client assets under management, boosting fees and net capital inflows. A good amount of capital is invested in research for new opportunities. With better research, return on investment can increase which increases clients confidence in you and will give you more money to invest.

FAQs.question: How do you deal with high levels of regulation? How have you budgeted for regulatory costs?
FAQs.answer: Government policies and regulations related to financial planning and advice affect the ways that financial planners and wealth managers can advise and invest on behalf of clients. To deal with high level of regulations, better customer service and products have to be offered to clients to increase revenue.

FAQs.question: How does your revenue respond to an increase in the S&P 500 index? How do you fare when there is volatility in the S&P 500?
FAQs.answer: The Standard & Poor's 500 index (S&P 500) is a benchmark used to evaluate US equity markets. Volatility in the S&P 500 is a proxy for volatility across equity markets, which greatly affects investment performance and industry revenue. With increase in S&P 500 index, investor uncertainty decreases which increases investment opportunities and increases demand for industry services. Prices do not change with volatility in S&P 500.

FAQs.question: How will do you take advantage of an increase in disposable income? Do you offer services to clients with a range of income levels?
FAQs.answer: The level of household disposable income influences investors' ability to invest their assets. Increase in per capita disposable income increases investment opportunities. Reaching out to current and potential clients for more investment helps increase revenue. Different services are offered for range of income levels as every client have different needs or target for investing their money.
